human.abstract: We present a novel method for discovering parallel sentences in comparable, non-parallel corpora. We train a maximum entropy classifier that, given a pair of sentences, can reliably determine whether or not they are translations of each other. Using this approach, we extract parallel data from large Chinese, Arabic, and English non-parallel newspaper corpora. We evaluate the quality of the extracted data by showing that it improves the performance of a state-of-the-art statistical machine translation system. We also show that a good-quality MT system can be built from scratch by starting with a very small parallel corpus (100,000 words) and exploiting a large non-parallel corpus. Thus, our method can be applied with great benefit to language pairs for which only scarce resources are available.
human.title: Improving Machine Translation Performance By Exploiting Non-Parallel Corpora

descriptions: This paper introduces a novel method for extracting parallel sentences from comparable, non-parallel corpora. By training a maximum entropy classifier to determine if sentences are translations of each other, the system is able to extract parallel data from large Chinese, Arabic, and English non-parallel newspaper corpora. The extracted data is shown to improve the performance of statistical machine translation systems significantly. The method is particularly beneficial for language pairs with limited parallel resources, enabling the creation of a quality MT system from scratch with minimal initial parallel data. The study demonstrates the robustness and efficiency of the approach, highlighting its potential for increasing the amount of training data for machine translation systems.

    <S sid="301" ssid="1">While there is a large body of work on bilingual comparable corpora, most of it is focused on learning word translations (Fung and Yee 1998; Rapp 1999; Diab and Finch 2000; Koehn and Knight 2000; Gaussier et al. 2004).</S>

    <S sid="347" ssid="1">The most important feature of our parallel sentence selection approach is its robustness.</S>
    <S sid="348" ssid="2">Comparable corpora are inherently noisy environments, where even similar content may be expressed in very different ways.</S>
    <S sid="349" ssid="3">Moreover, out-of-domain corpora introduce additional difficulties related to limited dictionary coverage.</S>
    <S sid="350" ssid="4">Therefore, the ability to reliably judge sentence pairs in isolation is crucial.</S>
    <S sid="351" ssid="5">Comparable corpora of interest are usually of large size; thus, processing them requires efficient algorithms.</S>
    <S sid="352" ssid="6">The computational processes involved in our system are quite modest.</S>
    <S sid="353" ssid="7">All the operations necessary for the classification of a sentence pair (filter, word alignment computation, and feature extraction) can be implemented efficiently and scaled up to very large amounts of data.</S>

llm.title: Improving Machine Translation Performance By Exploiting Non-Parallel Corpora

human.abstract: For centuries, the deep connection between languages has brought about major discoveries about human communication. In this paper we investigate how this powerful source of information can be exploited for unsupervised language learning. In particular, we study the task of morphological segmentation of multiple languages. We present a nonparametric Bayesian model that jointly induces morpheme segmentations of each language under consideration and at the same time identifies cross-lingual morpheme pator We apply our model to three Semitic languages: Arabic, Hebrew, Aramaic, as well as to English. Our results demonstrate that learning morphological models in tandem reduces error by up to 24% relative to monolingual models. Furthermore, we provide evidence that our joint model achieves better performance when applied to languages from the same family.
human.title: Unsupervised Multilingual Learning for Morphological Segmentation

descriptions: This paper explores the potential benefits of unsupervised multilingual learning for morphological segmentation across different languages. The model presented in the paper aims to capitalize on structural commonalities across languages to improve morphological analysis. By incorporating probabilistic segmentation approaches and hierarchical Bayesian models, the study demonstrates successful exploitation of cross-lingual patterns in the task of unsupervised morphological segmentation. Results indicate that related languages can provide significant improvements in segmentation accuracy, especially when character-to-character phonetic correspondences are considered as an abstract morpheme prior. The study opens avenues for applying multilingual models to other unsupervised analysis tasks and further investigating the impact of language relatedness on model performance.

human.abstract: Recognizing analogies, synonyms, anto nyms, and associations appear to be fourdistinct tasks, requiring distinct NLP al gorithms. In the past, the four tasks have been treated independently, using a widevariety of algorithms. These four seman tic classes, however, are a tiny sample of the full range of semantic phenomena, andwe cannot afford to create ad hoc algo rithms for each semantic phenomenon; weneed to seek a unified approach. We propose to subsume a broad range of phenom ena under analogies. To limit the scope of this paper, we restrict our attention to the subsumption of synonyms, antonyms, and associations. We introduce a supervised corpus-based machine learning algorithm for classifying analogous word pairs, and we show that it can solve multiple-choice SAT analogy questions, TOEFL synonymquestions, ESL synonym-antonym questions, and similar-associated-both ques tions from cognitive psychology.

descriptions: This paper presents a uniform approach to handling analogies, synonyms, antonyms, and associations by subsuming them under analogies. The authors propose a standard supervised machine learning algorithm, PairClass, for classifying word pairs based on semantic relations. The algorithm uses a large corpus to generate feature vectors and applies a support vector machine for classification. Experimental results show competitive performance in recognizing analogies and significant improvements in identifying synonyms, antonyms, and associations. The paper discusses the limitations of PairClass, the need for a large corpus, and suggests future applications in word sense disambiguation, information retrieval, and metaphor interpretation. The study aims to unify the field of semantics under the framework of analogies.

	<SECTION title="Discussion. " number="4">
			<S sid="143" ssid="1">The four experiments are summarized in Tables 8 and 9.</S>
			<S sid="144" ssid="2">For the first two experiments, where there are previous results, PairClass is not the best, butit performs competitively.</S>
			<S sid="145" ssid="3">For the second two ex periments, PairClass performs significantly abovethe baselines.</S>
			<S sid="146" ssid="4">However, the strength of this ap proach is not its performance on any one task, but the range of tasks it can handle.As far as we know, this is the first time a standard supervised learning algorithm has been ap plied to any of these four problems.</S>
			<S sid="147" ssid="5">The advantageof being able to cast these problems in the frame work of standard supervised learning problems isthat we can now exploit the huge literature on su pervised learning.</S>
			<S sid="148" ssid="6">Past work on these problems has required implicitly coding our knowledge ofthe nature of the task into the structure of the algo rithm.</S>
			<S sid="149" ssid="7">For example, the structure of the algorithmfor latent semantic analysis (LSA) implicitly con tains a theory of synonymy (Landauer and Dumais, 1997).</S>
			<S sid="150" ssid="8">The problem with this approach is that it can be very difficult to work out how to modify the algorithm if it does not behave the way we want.On the other hand, with a supervised learning algo rithm, we can put our knowledge into the labeling of the feature vectors, instead of putting it directly into the algorithm.</S>
			<S sid="151" ssid="9">This makes it easier to guide the system to the desired behaviour.With our approach to the SAT analogy ques tions, we are blurring the line between supervised and unsupervised learning, since the training set for a given SAT question consists of a single realpositive example (and a single ?virtual?</S>
			<S sid="152" ssid="10">or ?simulated?</S>
			<S sid="153" ssid="11">negative example).</S>
			<S sid="154" ssid="12">In effect, a single example (mason:stone) becomes a sui generis; it con stitutes a class of its own.</S>
			<S sid="155" ssid="13">It may be possible to apply the machinery of supervised learning toother problems that apparently call for unsupervised learning (for example, clustering or measur ing similarity), by using this sui generis device.</S>

	<SECTION title="Related Work. " number="5">
			<S sid="156" ssid="1">One of the first papers using supervised ma chine learning to classify word pairs was Rosarioand Hearst?s (2001) paper on classifying nounmodifier pairs in the medical domain.</S>
			<S sid="157" ssid="2">For ex ample, the noun-modifier expression brain biopsy was classified as Procedure.</S>
			<S sid="158" ssid="3">Rosario and Hearst(2001) constructed feature vectors for each nounmodifier pair using MeSH (Medical Subject Headings) and UMLS (Unified Medical Language System) as lexical resources.</S>
			<S sid="159" ssid="4">They then trained a neu ral network to distinguish 13 classes of semantic relations, such as Cause, Location, Measure, andInstrument.</S>
			<S sid="160" ssid="5">Nastase and Szpakowicz (2003) explored a similar approach to classifying general domain noun-modifier pairs, using WordNet and Roget?s Thesaurus as lexical resources.</S>

			<S sid="163" ssid="8">They used a nearest-neighbour learning algorithm to classify general-domain noun-modifier pairsinto 30 different classes of semantic relations.</S>
			<S sid="164" ssid="9">Tur ney (2006) later addressed the same problem using 8000 automatically generated patterns.One of the tasks in SemEval 2007 was the clas sification of semantic relations between nominals (Girju et al, 2007).</S>

			<S sid="166" ssid="11">The task attracted 14 teams who created 15 systems, all of which used supervised machine learning with features that were lexicon-based, corpus-based, or both.PairClass is most similar to the algorithm of Tur ney (2006), but it differs in the following ways:?</S>

	<SECTION title="Limitations and Future Work. " number="6">
			<S sid="183" ssid="1">The main limitation of PairClass is the need for a large corpus.</S>
			<S sid="184" ssid="2">Phrases that contain a pair of wordstend to be more rare than phrases that contain either of the members of the pair, thus a large cor pus is needed to ensure that sufficient numbers of phrases are found for each input word pair.</S>
			<S sid="185" ssid="3">The size of the corpus has a cost in terms of disk spaceand processing time.</S>
			<S sid="186" ssid="4">In the future, as hardware im proves, this will become less of an issue, but there may be ways to improve the algorithm, so that a smaller corpus is sufficient.Another area for future work is to apply Pair Class to more tasks.</S>
			<S sid="187" ssid="5">WordNet includes more thana dozen semantic relations (e.g., synonyms, hy ponyms, hypernyms, meronyms, holonyms, and antonyms).</S>
			<S sid="188" ssid="6">PairClass should be applicable to allof these relations.</S>
			<S sid="189" ssid="7">Other potential applications in clude any task that involves semantic relations, such as word sense disambiguation, informationretrieval, information extraction, and metaphor in terpretation.</S>

	<SECTION title="Conclusion. " number="7">
			<S sid="190" ssid="1">In this paper, we have described a uniform approach to analogies, synonyms, antonyms, and as sociations, in which all of these phenomena are subsumed by analogies.</S>
			<S sid="191" ssid="2">We view the problem ofrecognizing analogies as the classification of se mantic relations between words.</S>
			<S sid="192" ssid="3">We believe that most of our lexical knowledge is relational, not attributional.</S>
			<S sid="193" ssid="4">That is, meaning is largely about relations among words, rather thanproperties of individual words, considered in isolation.</S>
			<S sid="194" ssid="5">For example, consider the knowledge en coded in WordNet: much of the knowledge in WordNet is embedded in the graph structure that connects words.</S>
			<S sid="195" ssid="6">Analogies of the form A:B::C:D are calledproportional analogies.</S>
			<S sid="196" ssid="7">These types of lowerlevel analogies may be contrasted with higher level analogies, such as the analogy between the solar system and Rutherford?s model of the atom (Falkenhainer et al, 1989), which are sometimes called conceptual analogies.</S>
			<S sid="197" ssid="8">We believe that the difference between these two types is largely a matter of complexity.</S>
			<S sid="198" ssid="9">A higher-level analogy is composed of many lower-level analogies.</S>
			<S sid="199" ssid="10">Progresswith algorithms for processing lower-level analo gies will eventually contribute to algorithms for higher-level analogies.The idea of subsuming a broad range of semantic phenomena under analogies has been sug gested by many researchers.</S>
			<S sid="200" ssid="11">Minsky (1986) wrote, ?How do we ever understand anything?</S>
			<S sid="201" ssid="12">Almost always, I think, by using one or another kind of analogy.?</S>
			<S sid="202" ssid="13">Hofstadter (2007) claimed, ?all meaningcomes from analogies.?</S>
			<S sid="203" ssid="14">In NLP, analogical algo rithms have been applied to machine translation(Lepage and Denoual, 2005), morphology (Lep age, 1998), and semantic relations (Turney and Littman, 2005).</S>
			<S sid="204" ssid="15">Analogy provides a frameworkthat has the potential to unify the field of seman tics.</S>
			<S sid="205" ssid="16">This paper is a small step towards that goal.</S>
